importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Coca-Cola began rolling out its cane sugar soda in the United States, following a policy shift prompted by President Donald Trump's earlier advocacy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the article's publication and the rollout of the cane sugar soda, indicating a recent policy shift in Coca-Cola's product formulation.

keyTakeAways: Coca-Cola has begun selling a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in select U.S. cities and retailers.
The switch was prompted by a demand from President Donald Trump, who advocated for the use of cane sugar over high-fructose corn syrup.
This move aligns with advocacy by Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., the U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services, who has criticized high-fructose corn syrup.
While health experts note that sugary sodas are unhealthy regardless of the sweetener, Coca-Cola is expanding healthier beverage options, including sugar-free sodas and bottled water.
Coca-Cola Zero Sugar saw a 14% global volume increase in the third quarter, and company shares rose over 3% in early trading, showing market confidence in healthier product lines.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Coca-Cola has begun rolling out a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in select U.S. cities, responding to a public demand from former President Donald Trump and pressure from Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., who has long criticized corn syrup. While health experts note that all sugary sodas are unhealthy, the shift reflects a broader trend within Coca-Cola toward healthier products, including the successful relaunch of BodyArmor and growth in sugar-free offerings like Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which saw a 14% global volume increase in the third quarter of 2025. This development highlights the intersection of political influence, public health advocacy, and corporate product innovation in the beverage industry.
title: Coca-Cola’s Trump-approved soda begins to roll out in the United States
